item.title: R Crash Course II
item.description:
• Intro
  • Downloading Data
    • Data Structure
    • Avoiding Common Mistakes

Intro

This tutorial will demonstrate the power of data.table for cleaning and analyzing data. I will apply it to New York Cityâs Restaurant Inspection data.1 As a quick background, since 2010, New York City has required restaurants to post their health grades and inspection results. During inspection, for every health code violation, a restaurant earns points. Therefore, the lower a restaurantâs score, the safer the restaurant. With that out of the way, letâs dig into the data like itâs a delicious slice of New York style pizza.2

To guide ourselves, we will try to answer two questions:

  1. Which borough has the safest food?
  2. Which type of cuisine has the safest food?

Downloading Data

In order to produce high-quality research, your data analysis and cleaning should be clear and transparent. That means your code should document every step from downloading the raw data to polishing your cleaned data that you ultimately run your analysis on. data.table makes it easy to go from source to solution. Letâs download our data.

library(data.table)
food <- fread("https://data.cityofnewyork.us/api/views/43nn-pn8j/rows.csv?accessType=DOWNLOAD")
## Warning in fread("./food.csv"): Bumped column 7 to type character on data
## row 505, field contains '__________'. Coercing previously read values in
## this column from logical, integer or numeric back to character which may
## not be lossless; e.g., if '00' and '000' occurred before they will now
## be just '0', and there may be inconsistencies with treatment of ',,' and
## ',NA,' too (if they occurred in this column before the bump). If this
## matters please rerun and set 'colClasses' to 'character' for this column.
## Please note that column type detection uses a sample of 1,000 rows (100
## rows at 10 points) so hopefully this message should be very rare. If
## reporting to datatable-help, please rerun and include the output from
## verbose=TRUE.

Uh oh, we got a warning message! The good thing is that the error is quite informative. data.table did the right thing and we can rest easy.3

Data Structure

Now what does our data look like? One easy way of examining the data is to use the str() command (which is short for âstructureâ). We see that the data is organized as a data.table and every column is stored as a character except CAMIS and SCORE.

str(food)
## Classes 'data.table' and 'data.frame':   390508 obs. of  18 variables:
##  $ CAMIS                : int  50002395 40885333 50007460 40368157 40937978 50007874 41194745 41327743 41414060 41690753 ...
##  $ DBA                  : chr  "EMPIRE SZECHUAN VILLAGE" "SWISS INTERNATIONAL AIRLINES LOUNGE" "KRUST PIZZA" "ELEPHANT & CASTLE" ...
##  $ BORO                 : chr  "STATEN ISLAND" "QUEENS" "MANHATTAN" "MANHATTAN" ...
##  $ BUILDING             : chr  "4373" "4" "226" "68" ...
##  $ STREET               : chr  "AMBOY ROAD" "JFK INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT" "E 14TH ST" "GREENWICH AVENUE" ...
##  $ ZIPCODE              : chr  "10312" "11430" "10003" "10011" ...
##  $ PHONE                : chr  "7182272888" "7187514940" "2125108869" "2122431400" ...
##  $ CUISINE DESCRIPTION  : chr  "Chinese" "American" "Pizza" "American" ...
##  $ INSPECTION DATE      : chr  "12/01/2015" "12/10/2014" "12/19/2017" "05/22/2015" ...
##  $ ACTION               : chr  "Violations were cited in the following area(s)." "Violations were cited in the following area(s)." "Violations were cited in the following area(s)." "Violations were cited in the following area(s)." ...
##  $ VIOLATION CODE       : chr  "06C" "04H" "04L" "06F" ...
##  $ VIOLATION DESCRIPTION: chr  "Food not protected from potential source of contamination during storage, preparation, transportation, display or service." "Raw, cooked or prepared food is adulterated, contaminated, cross-contaminated, or not discarded in accordance with HACCP plan." "Evidence of mice or live mice present in facility's food and/or non-food areas." "Wiping cloths soiled or not stored in sanitizing solution." ...
##  $ CRITICAL FLAG        : chr  "Critical" "Critical" "Critical" "Critical" ...
##  $ SCORE                : int  21 13 24 12 7 10 7 32 7 7 ...
##  $ GRADE                : chr  "" "" "Z" "" ...
##  $ GRADE DATE           : chr  "" "" "12/19/2017" "" ...
##  $ RECORD DATE          : chr  "01/02/2018" "01/02/2018" "01/02/2018" "01/02/2018" ...
##  $ INSPECTION TYPE      : chr  "Cycle Inspection / Initial Inspection" "Cycle Inspection / Initial Inspection" "Cycle Inspection / Re-inspection" "Cycle Inspection / Initial Inspection" ...
##  - attr(*, ".internal.selfref")=<externalptr>

Avoiding Common Mistakes

Now, before we go much further, letâs take a second and avoid some common traps.

Premature Optimization/Organization: The data types are incorrect and there are entries that should be cleaned up. For example, there is a phone number entry â_________â that should be replaced with a blank value. We could convert the dates to Date types and ZIP codes to integer types. However, our mission is to analyze food safety by borough and cuisine. This does not require information about dates or ZIP codes. Do not get distracted. We can organize this if this data will become an instrumental part of our future research. For now, it is too early to organize and optimize the data. This mistake is common because itâs not a question of âifâ (because you should clean and organize any data that you use), but a question of âwhenâ (and for initial analysis, the time is not now).

Too Many Variables: Decide what you actually need for your analysis. It is easy to get carried away exploring the data and forgetting what you meant to do. If you come up with new questions for analysis, write them down for later and revisit them once you finish your intended task. Furthermore, as you deal with bigger and bigger datasets, it will be infeasible to load everything into memory. Therefore, you must select the subset that you actually need. This also helps ensure you keep focused on the mission.

Letâs apply this thinking to our problem. First, variables, what do we need? We only care about the safety scores of restaurants by borough and cuisine. Therefore, we need BORO, CUISINE DESCRIPTION, and SCORE. There are also a lot of different inspection types and inspection dates, letâs keep those because we will want to look at changes over time and only look at routine food inspections. We also want to keep the restaurant ID (CAMIS) so we can tell different observations apart.

food <- food[, .(CAMIS, `INSPECTION TYPE`, `INSPECTION DATE`, BORO, `CUISINE DESCRIPTION`, SCORE)]
print(food)
##            CAMIS                               INSPECTION TYPE
##      1: 50002395         Cycle Inspection / Initial Inspection
##      2: 40885333         Cycle Inspection / Initial Inspection
##      3: 50007460              Cycle Inspection / Re-inspection
##      4: 40368157         Cycle Inspection / Initial Inspection
##      5: 40937978              Cycle Inspection / Re-inspection
##     ---                                                       
## 390504: 40865946              Cycle Inspection / Re-inspection
## 390505: 50002502       Smoke-Free Air Act / Initial Inspection
## 390506: 41139263              Cycle Inspection / Re-inspection
## 390507: 50047736 Pre-permit (Operational) / Initial Inspection
## 390508: 50046278      Pre-permit (Operational) / Re-inspection
##         INSPECTION DATE          BORO CUISINE DESCRIPTION SCORE
##      1:      12/01/2015 STATEN ISLAND             Chinese    21
##      2:      12/10/2014        QUEENS            American    13
##      3:      12/19/2017     MANHATTAN               Pizza    24
##      4:      05/22/2015     MANHATTAN            American    12
##      5:      11/06/2014         BRONX            American     7
##     ---                                                        
## 390504:      10/07/2016     MANHATTAN             Seafood     5
## 390505:      10/03/2014     MANHATTAN      Middle Eastern    NA
## 390506:      01/07/2015     MANHATTAN             Italian    15
## 390507:      10/13/2016      BROOKLYN              French     6
## 390508:      06/27/2016         BRONX             Chicken    11

Now weâre cookinâ!4 This is already looking like some data we can handle!

avg_score_borough <- food[, .(Score = mean(SCORE, na.rm = TRUE)), by = BORO]
print(avg_score_borough)
##             BORO    Score
## 1: STATEN ISLAND 19.44175
## 2:        QUEENS 18.57633
## 3:     MANHATTAN 19.03793
## 4:         BRONX 18.12669
## 5:      BROOKLYN 19.29889
## 6:       Missing 17.27273

Surprisingly, the Bronx has the safest restaurants on average!5

  1. Delicious food is fun, food poisoning isnât.â©

  2. Pizza is delicious no matter where you are.â©

  3. If you want details, basically, data.table thought column 7 was an integer or numeric column, but had to convert that to a character instead. It turns out data.tableâs initial guess was actually right (since column 7 is for phone numbers), but the â_______â is not numeric, so to try and preserve data, data.table read in column 7 as a string. fread() guesses the column type by working its way through the ordered list logical, integer, integer64, double, and characterâ©

  4. pun intendedâ©

  5. It turns out there are a lot of mistakes in the above analysis. I will correct them in the next post. To name a few, first, this is pooled across all inspection types and we likely just care about regular food safety inspections. Second, an observation in this data set is a restaurant violation and hence restaurants with more violations show up multiple times with the same score. We will need to remove duplicate restaurant grades. Finally, these scores are across 2014-2017. Splitting up by year would be better to identify improvement.â©

item.title: Web Scraping Using R
item.description:
• Web Scraping
  • Project Background
  • How Scraping Works
  • Getting Prices

Web Scraping

For the uninitiated, web scraping is a way of extracting data from websites. Why would anyone be interested in this? There is a lot of data made available on the web, but it is not always in easily downloadable formats. Or, as is more often the case, a human can only highlight, copy, and paste so many times before carpal tunnel sets in and oneâs mind begins to melt. We created software so computers can do the tasks we do not want to, so letâs take advantage of that!

In this post, I will guide you through using Hadley Wickhamâs rvest package to scrape prices from Walmart.com. I am currently collecting this data for a personal research project, but if you are interested just contact me!

For an advanced version of scraping (extracting JavaScript elements), see my other web scraping tutorial.

Project Background

Online prices can be different from offline prices and for a long time, large companies like Target and Walmart did not match their online prices (they only started in 2013 and 2014, respectively).1 2 Even now, Macyâs still does not match the prices on their website.3

In order to get the offline prices of goods, you would have to go into the store and compare the shelf price to the website price. However, in November 2017, Walmart actually increased its online prices and posted both the online and in-store price on its website.4 This change creates a unique opportunity to generate a fascinating data set of online and offline prices from one of the worldâs largest retailers.

How Scraping Works

There are a wide variety of web scraping tools. rvest uses HTML scraping, which means that after feeding it a URL, it can scrape various elements of the webpage directly from the underlying HTML code. When using this strategy, you must put in the effort to identify the HTML elements that you want to extract. You could do this by directly looking at the HTML and then figuring out which attributes to scrape. However, there is an easier way. The SelectorGadget tool allows you to click on the elements you want to extract and it tells you the HTML attributes that are underlying the element you clicked.

Getting Prices

For this exercise, I will get the prices of Kraft Macaroni and Cheese.5 Before beginning, I looked at what data was available on the page and identified specific fields that I wanted to capture. Below are the fields I will capture:

  • Date
  • Product Name
  • Online Price
  • In-Store Price (if available)
  • Online Sale Price (if applicable)
  • In-Store Sale Price (if applicable)
library(rvest)
## Loading required package: xml2
kraft <- "https://www.walmart.com/search/?query=kraft%20macaroni%20and%20cheese"
price <- read_html(kraft) %>% 
  html_nodes(".product-title-link , .clearfix")


trip <- "http://www.tripadvisor.com/Hotel_Review-g37209-d1762915-Reviews-JW_Marriott_Indianapolis-Indianapolis_Indiana.html"
apple <- read_html(trip) %>% 
  html_nodes(".partial_entry")

pear <- read_html(trip) %>%
  html_nodes("#REVIEWS .innerBubble")

  1. See Targetâs January 8, 2013 press release âTarget Announces New Year-Round Price Match of Online Retailersââ©

  2. See Walmartâs November 19, 2014 press release âWalmart Statement Regarding Online Price Match Policyââ©

  3. See Macyâs Pricing Policy for Online Merchandise accessed December 16, 2017.â©

  4. See November 12, 2017 WSJ article Now Featured on Wal-Martâs Website: Higher Prices Than Storesâ©

  5. Itâs the cheesiest.â©

item.title: Web Scraping Using R II
item.description:
• Introduction

Introduction

This is a tutorial for more advanced web scraping of JavaScript elements. I will use the same example as in my beginner web scraping tutorial. In that example, I was scraping price and product information from Walmart.com for Kraft Macaroni and Cheese.1

This is because the HTML contains a lot of extra information that is not visible on the page and most of it was contained within JavaScript. The JavaScript contained a lot of fascinating extra information including the following:

  • Product name
  • UPC code
  • Sellerâs name and ID
  • Retail price
  • Sale price
  • In-store price
  • Quantity available (inventory)

From an economic perspective, these extra fields are invaluable (especially the UPC code). The inventory count is also fascinating.

  1. Itâs the cheesiest.â©

item.title: A World Without Borders Revisited: The Impact of Sales Tax Collection on Shopping and Search
Example Talk
item.description: Embed your slides or video here using shortcodes. Further details can easily be added using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description:
R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)
##      speed           dist       
##  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
##  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
##  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
##  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
##  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
##  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
fit
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)        speed  
##     -17.579        3.932

Including Plots

You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)

Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.

item.title: Econ 103
item.description:
Grades and Questions:

Your grades are posted on Canvas. If you have questions, post them on Piazza. My office hours are on Tuesdays from 8-9AM and on Wednesdays from 4-5PM (right before class). If you need to make an appointment, just email me.

Course Documents:

  • Syllabus
  • How to do well in Econ 103: Some tips for the course.
  • Combinations and Permutations: A review
  • Random Variables Handout Useful discussion about probability distributions: NYU Stern, Cloudera
  • 7 Tips for Interpreting Macroeconomic Data (Jason Furman, CEA Chairman) [pdf version]
  • Confidence Interval Refinement (Add 2 Successes and 2 Failures)

Forecasting and Polling Module

  • Overview of Common Issues in Polling and Survey Design (Source: Pew Research)
  • Slides

R Project Resources:

  • R Project Assignment
  • RMarkdown Cheatsheet
  • RMarkdown Tutorial
  • Tips on Regression in R

Lectures:

  • Chapter 1 Background and Motivation [Quiz]
  • Chapter 2 Summary Statistics and Z-Scores [Quiz]
  • Chapter 3 Probability [Quiz]
  • Chapter 4 (Updated) Random Variables (Discrete Version) [Quiz] [Video]
  • Chapter 5 Random Variables (Continuous Version) [Quiz][Video1][Video2]
  • Chapter 6 Sampling and Bias [Quiz]
  • Chapter 7 Confidence Intervals [Video]
  • Chapter 8 Hypothesis Testing [Video1] [Video2] [Video3] [Quiz]
  • Chapter 9 Regression [Video]
